questions.text: Most common organism associated with acute sinusitis is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rhinovirus. Acute sinusitis is most commonly initiated by a viral infection, with rhinovirus being the primary culprit. Rhinovirus, which is responsible for the common cold, frequently causes inflammation and mucosal edema in the nasal passages and sinuses. This viral-induced inflammation can lead to blockage of the sinus drainage pathways, resulting in acute sinusitis. Although bacterial superinfection (commonly by Streptococcus pneumoniae) may occur later, the initial and most common cause is viral, particularly rhinovirus. Incorrect Options: (B) S. pneumoniae Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common bacterial pathogen in cases of acute bacterial sinusitis. However, overall, viral infections (especially due to rhinovirus) are much more common causes of acute sinusitis. (C) S. aureus Staphylococcus aureus is not typically associated with acute sinusitis. It is more commonly implicated in other types of infections and is not a frequent cause of sinus inflammation. (D) Aspergillosis Aspergillus species cause fungal sinusitis, which is usually seen in immunocompromised patients or in chronic sinusitis cases. It is not a common cause of acute sinusitis.

questions.text: Chronic sinusitis is defined as when the signs and symptoms last for more than
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 12 weeks. Chronic sinusitis is defined as sinus inflammation where the signs and symptoms persist for 12 weeks or more, despite attempts at appropriate medical treatment. This time frame helps distinguish chronic sinusitis from acute or subacute presentations. Incorrect Options: (A) 3 weeks A duration of 3 weeks falls within the acute phase of sinusitis rather than the chronic phase. (B) 4 weeks Similarly, 4 weeks is too short to be considered chronic sinusitis and is still generally classified as acute or possibly subacute. (C) 6 weeks While 6 weeks might be indicative of a prolonged or subacute process, it does not meet the accepted definition of chronic sinusitis, which requires a duration of at least 12 weeks.atment.

questions.text: Pediatric Sinusitis usually involves:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Maxillary sinus and anterior ethmoids. In pediatric patients, the maxillary sinuses and anterior ethmoid air cells are the most developed and commonly affected sites in sinusitis. These sinuses are present and functional at a younger age, making them the primary sites of infection when children develop sinusitis. Incorrect Options: (B) Maxillary sinus and posterior ethmoids Posterior ethmoids are less developed in children and are not typically involved in pediatric sinusitis. The primary involvement is usually limited to the anterior parts of the ethmoid complex. (C) Frontal sinus and anterior ethmoids The frontal sinuses generally develop later in childhood (around 7–8 years of age) and do not become fully functional until adolescence. Therefore, they are not commonly involved in pediatric sinusitis compared to the maxillary and anterior ethmoid sinuses. (D) Frontal sinus and posterior ethmoids Both the frontal sinuses and the posterior ethmoids are not fully developed in the pediatric population. Their involvement in sinusitis is uncommon in children, making this option inappropriate for describing pediatric sinusitis.

questions.text: 70 yrs old patient suffering from chronic sinusitis since last 4 yrs complains of headache, diplopia and proptosis:Study the given slide and choose most inappropriate statement ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cystic tender swelling Cystic tender swelling. In the context of a frontal sinus mucocoele, the swelling is characteristically cystic but usually non-tender. A mucocoele is a mucus-filled cyst that develops due to chronic sinusitis and blockage of the sinus drainage, and it typically presents as a painless, non-tender swelling despite its significant mass effect that can lead to headache, diplopia, and proptosis. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Displaces the eyeball downward and laterally This is a correct statement. A frontal sinus mucocoele can expand and displace the orbital contents. Due to its location, it may push the eyeball downward and laterally, which correlates with the patient's symptoms. Option (C) Egg shell crackling can be elicited This is also correct. On palpation, the thinning bony walls of the sinus due to the expanding mucocoele can produce an "egg shell" crackling sensation, which is a recognized clinical sign. Option (D) Treatment is frontoethmoidectomy This statement is correct. The standard treatment involves surgical intervention, such as a frontoethmoidectomy, to re-establish drainage of the frontal sinus into the middle meatus and relieve the mass effect.

questions.text: Chronic sinusitis in children is usually confined to :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ethmoid sinus. In children, the ethmoid sinuses are the most well-developed and are present at birth, making them the most commonly involved in chronic sinusitis. Their central location and close relationship to the nasal cavity predispose them to inflammatory processes. Additionally, the other sinuses (maxillary, frontal, and sphenoid) are either less developed or develop later in childhood, which limits their involvement in chronic sinusitis in younger patients. (B) Maxillary sinus While the maxillary sinuses do develop during childhood, they are not as prominently involved in chronic sinusitis in children as the ethmoid sinuses. Their involvement tends to be more common in older children and adults. (C) Frontal sinus The frontal sinuses typically do not fully develop until around 7–8 years of age and, therefore, are rarely the primary site of chronic sinusitis in younger children. (D) Sphenoid sinus The sphenoid sinuses develop even later in childhood (often during adolescence), so they are not commonly implicated in chronic sinusitis in children.

questions.text: Most common presentation of chronic sinusitis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Purulent nasal discharge. Chronic sinusitis typically presents with a persistent, thick, and often foul-smelling mucopurulent discharge. This discharge is a direct consequence of the ongoing inflammation and infection within the sinus cavities, making it one of the most frequently reported symptoms by patients suffering from chronic sinusitis. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Nasal obstruction or blockage While nasal obstruction is a common symptom in chronic sinusitis due to mucosal swelling and edema, it is generally not considered the most common presentation when compared to purulent discharge. Many patients report a combination of symptoms, but the presence of purulent discharge is often the key indicator of a chronic inflammatory process. Option (C) Hyposmia or anosmia Loss of smell is also frequently seen in chronic sinusitis because inflammation can interfere with the olfactory pathways. However, while significant, this symptom is secondary to the discharge and does not occur as consistently as purulent nasal discharge. Option (D) Headache Headache can occur in chronic sinusitis due to pressure changes within the sinuses or secondary inflammation. Nevertheless, it is less specific and less consistently observed than purulent discharge, which remains the hallmark symptom

questions.text: Investigation of choice for Acute sinusitis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CT Scan. CT scanning is the investigation of choice for acute sinusitis because it provides high-resolution images that allow for a detailed evaluation of the sinus anatomy. It is excellent in detecting mucosal thickening, air-fluid levels, and any obstruction within the sinus drainage pathways. CT also offers clear visualization of the bony structures, which is important in assessing any complications or anatomical variations that might predispose the patient to sinusitis. Incorrect Options: Option (B) X-ray (Water’s View) While a Water’s view (occipitomental view) X-ray can provide some information regarding the paranasal sinuses, its resolution and sensitivity are limited compared to CT scan. It may miss subtle mucosal changes or early sinus pathology and does not provide the detailed bony anatomy that CT does. Option (C) MRI MRI is generally not the first-line investigation for acute sinusitis. Although it is useful for evaluating soft tissue and intracranial complications, CT scan remains superior for assessing the bony structures and overall sinus anatomy in acute settings. Option (D) Ultrasonography Ultrasonography is not commonly used for evaluating acute sinusitis due to its limitations in imaging bony structures and deeper sinus cavities. It is not as sensitive or specific as CT scan for diagnosing sinus pathology.

questions.text: Patients suffering from cystic fibrosis and sinusitis have higher risk for developing :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Both. In patients with cystic fibrosis, the thick, viscous secretions in the respiratory tract—including the sinuses—create an ideal environment for bacterial colonization. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is particularly common due to its ability to thrive in these conditions, leading to chronic infections. Similarly, Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) has also emerged as a significant pathogen in CF patients. Therefore, individuals with cystic fibrosis and sinusitis are at an increased risk for developing infections with both Pseudomonas and MRSA. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Pseudomonal infections While it is true that Pseudomonas infections are common in CF patients, considering this option alone would ignore the increased risk of MRSA, making it incomplete. Option (B) Methicillin resistant S. aureus infections This is also a valid risk in CF patients; however, it is not the only pathogen of concern. Focusing solely on MRSA would similarly overlook the high prevalence of Pseudomonas infections. Option (D) None This option is incorrect because both Pseudomonas and MRSA are known to be significant pathogens in patients with cystic fibrosis and sinusitis.

questions.text: Rhinocerebral disease is caused by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mucor Rhinocerebral disease, often referred to as rhinocerebral mucormycosis, is a severe fungal infection predominantly caused by fungi in the order Mucorales, with Mucor species being one of the primary culprits. This condition typically occurs in immunocompromised individuals, particularly in patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus (especially those with ketoacidosis) and other immunosuppressive conditions. The fungus invades the nasal passages and sinuses, and can rapidly spread to the brain, making early diagnosis and aggressive treatment critical. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Pseudomonas Pseudomonas is a bacterium known for causing various infections, particularly in hospitalized patients or those with compromised immune systems, but it is not associated with rhinocerebral mucormycosis. Option (B) Methicillin resistant S. aureus (MRSA) MRSA is a resistant bacterial strain responsible for many infections, including skin and soft tissue infections, but it does not cause rhinocerebral disease of fungal origin. Option (D) None Since Mucor is the established cause of rhinocerebral mucormycosis, the answer cannot be "None."

questions.text: Sinus most commonly involved in mucoceles is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The correct answer is (A) Frontal sinus. Mucoceles are mucus-filled cystic lesions that develop due to the obstruction of the sinus drainage pathway. The frontal sinus is the most commonly involved site because its narrow drainage pathway (the frontal recess) is particularly prone to blockage, leading to mucus retention and subsequent expansion of the sinus. Over time, the expanding mucocele can cause bony erosion and even affect adjacent structures, such as the orbit. Incorrect Options: Option (B) Maxillary sinus Mucoceles can occur in the maxillary sinus, but they are much less common compared to those in the frontal sinus. The maxillary sinus has a wider ostium, making complete obstruction less likely. Option (C) Sphenoid sinus Sphenoid sinus mucoceles are rare. Although they can have serious complications due to the proximity to vital structures like the optic nerve and cavernous sinus, they are not the most common site. Option (D) Ethmoid sinus While mucoceles can develop in the ethmoid sinuses, their incidence is lower than in the frontal sinus. The frontal sinus remains the most predisposed due to its complex drainage and narrow outflow tract

questions.text: All are true regarding mucocele of frontal sinus except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cystic tender swelling. Frontal sinus mucoceles are mucus-filled cystic lesions that expand gradually due to obstruction of the sinus drainage pathway. They typically present as a non-tender swelling. Despite being cystic, these lesions are usually painless unless secondary infection or inflammation occurs. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Displaces the eyeball downward and laterally This is true. As the mucocele enlarges, it can exert pressure on the adjacent orbital contents, leading to displacement of the eyeball in a downward and lateral direction. Option (C) Egg shell crackling can be elicited This is also true. Due to the gradual expansion and subsequent thinning of the bony walls of the frontal sinus, palpation may reveal an "eggshell" crackling sensation. Option (D) Treatment is frontoethmoidectomy This is correct. The standard surgical treatment for a frontal sinus mucocele is frontoethmoidectomy, which aims to re-establish proper drainage of the frontal sinus into the nasal cavity.

questions.text: Traid of “Kartagener’s Syndrome” includes all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Azoospermia. Kartagener’s syndrome is a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia and is classically defined by a triad of features: chronic rhinitis/sinusitis (and often otitis media), bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. In addition, patients often experience infertility due to impaired ciliary function, which leads to immotile sperm. However, this does not equate to azoospermia (the complete absence of sperm); rather, sperm are present but with reduced motility. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Chronic rhinitis/sinusitis/otitis media This is a typical feature of Kartagener’s syndrome because defective ciliary motion in the respiratory tract results in chronic inflammation and infection. Option (B) Bronchiectasis Bronchiectasis is commonly seen in these patients due to the inability to clear mucus effectively from the airways, leading to chronic infections and airway dilation. Option (C) Situs inversus Situs inversus is one of the hallmark features of Kartagener’s syndrome and occurs due to abnormal ciliary function during embryogenesis.

questions.text: A young female with a long standing history of sinusitis presents with frequent fever along with personality changes and headaches of recent onset. Fundus examination revealed papilledema. The most likely diagnosis is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Frontal lobe abscess. In a young female with a long history of sinusitis, particularly involving the frontal sinuses, the development of a frontal lobe abscess is a well-known complication. The clinical presentation of personality changes and headaches, coupled with papilledema on fundus examination, strongly suggests increased intracranial pressure secondary to an intracerebral abscess. The frontal lobe is especially vulnerable because of its proximity to the frontal sinuses, and the spread of infection can occur via direct extension or through venous channels. Incorrect Options: Option (B) Meningitis Meningitis usually presents with fever, neck stiffness, and photophobia, but it rarely causes focal neurological deficits like personality changes or localized papilledema unless there is accompanying intracranial pathology. Hence, while meningitis can occur, it does not fit the complete clinical picture here. Option (C) Encephalitis Encephalitis typically results from viral infections and is associated with diffuse cerebral involvement, which might cause altered mental status, but it is not commonly linked with chronic sinusitis. The focal nature of the symptoms (personality change) and the presence of papilledema are less characteristic of encephalitis. Option (D) Frontal bone osteomyelitis Frontal bone osteomyelitis involves infection of the frontal bone and might occur secondary to sinusitis; however, it does not typically lead to significant intracranial pressure effects such as papilledema or the specific neuropsychiatric symptoms seen with a frontal lobe abscess.

questions.text: Sinocutaneous Fistula: usually begins as a :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Frontal osteomyelitis. Sinocutaneous fistula, particularly in the context of the sinuses, usually begins as an infection in the frontal bone. Chronic or inadequately treated frontal sinusitis can lead to osteomyelitis of the frontal bone. Over time, this bone infection may erode the bone and extend to the overlying soft tissues, eventually forming a fistulous tract that connects the frontal sinus to the skin surface. Option (A) Ethmoidal osteomyelitis While the ethmoid sinuses can be involved in sinusitis, osteomyelitis of the ethmoid bone is less likely to lead to a sinocutaneous fistula due to its deeper, more central location and the bony architecture. Option (B) Maxillary osteomyelitis Osteomyelitis of the maxilla usually does not result in a sinocutaneous fistula, as the maxillary sinus and its bony walls are not typically predisposed to this type of fistula formation compared to the frontal region. Option (D) Sphenoidal osteomyelitis The sphenoid sinus is located deep within the skull, and infection in this area rarely leads to a fistula that communicates with the cutaneous surface.

questions.text: Earliest stage of orbital complication is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Preseptal Cellulitis. Preseptal cellulitis, also known as periorbital cellulitis, is the earliest orbital complication. It involves an infection of the eyelid and the surrounding soft tissues anterior to the orbital septum. This stage is characterized by eyelid swelling, redness, and pain, without any impairment of ocular motility or vision, which distinguishes it from more severe orbital involvement. Option (A) Orbital Cellulitis Orbital cellulitis is a more advanced stage of infection where the infection extends beyond the orbital septum into the orbital tissues. It presents with pain on eye movement, restricted ocular motility, and sometimes decreased vision, making it a later complication compared to preseptal cellulitis. Option (B) Subperiosteal Abscess A subperiosteal abscess is an even later stage, where the infection has progressed to form a collection of pus between the bone and the periosteum. This condition is more severe and often requires prompt surgical intervention. Option (D) Orbital Abscess An orbital abscess is the most advanced and serious complication, involving a localized pus collection within the orbital tissues. It poses significant risks to vision and requires urgent management.

questions.text: Most common complication of endoscopic sinus surgery :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Synechia. Synechia refers to adhesions or scar tissue that can form between the nasal structures, commonly between the middle turbinate and the lateral nasal wall, after endoscopic sinus surgery. This is the most common complication due to the mucosal trauma and subsequent healing process that occurs during and after surgery, which can lead to abnormal tissue adherence. Incorrect Options: (B) Retrobulbar Hematoma Although retrobulbar hematoma is a serious complication, it is rare and typically results from inadvertent orbital injury rather than being a common outcome of the surgery. (C) Diplopia Diplopia, or double vision, can occur if there is orbital involvement or injury during the procedure. However, it is not as frequently encountered as synechia in endoscopic sinus surgery. (D) Seromas Seromas, which are collections of serous fluid, are not common complications in endoscopic sinus surgery. The typical postoperative issues are more related to mucosal healing and adhesion formation rather than seroma development.

questions.text: Retrobulbar Hematoma as a complication of FESS occur from retration injury of the :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anterior ethmoid artery. During Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS), retraction or manipulation in the region of the medial orbital wall can injure the anterior ethmoid artery. This artery runs close to the ethmoid sinus and the orbit, and an injury to it may lead to bleeding into the retrobulbar space, resulting in a retrobulbar hematoma. This complication is particularly concerning due to the risk of vision loss from increased orbital pressure. Incorrect Options: Option (B) Posterior ethmoid artery The posterior ethmoid artery primarily supplies the posterior ethmoid air cells and is less likely to be involved in orbital retraction injuries during FESS. Option (C) Sphenopalatine artery The sphenopalatine artery is located more laterally and supplies the nasal cavity and maxillary sinus. It is not typically associated with retrobulbar hematoma during FESS. Option (D) Lingual artery The lingual artery supplies the tongue and is anatomically unrelated to the structures involved in FESS, thus not a source of retrobulbar hematoma.bossment (frontal sinus obliteration)

questions.text: Symptoms of sinusitis are all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Diplopia. Diplopia (double vision) is not a typical symptom of uncomplicated sinusitis. While sinusitis usually presents with symptoms such as nasal blockage, facial pain, facial edema, and even blood-stained rhinorrhea (especially when there is irritation or minor mucosal bleeding), diplopia is usually indicative of an extension of infection into the orbital region or other complications. In uncomplicated sinusitis, the orbit is not involved; therefore, double vision is not expected. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Blood stained rhinorrhea – This can occur in sinusitis due to inflammation and irritation of the nasal mucosa, leading to minor bleeding. Option (B) Facial edema – Swelling of the facial tissues is a common feature of sinusitis as a result of the inflammatory process. Option (C) Nasal blockage – Nasal obstruction is a hallmark symptom of sinusitis, resulting from mucosal swelling and mucus accumulation.

questions.text: Sphenoid sinusitis pain is referred most commonly to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Occiput is the most common site for referred pain in sphenoid sinusitis. The sphenoid sinus is located deep within the skull near the base and close to structures innervated by branches of the trigeminal nerve and upper cervical nerves. Inflammation in the sphenoid sinus often produces pain that radiates to the occipital region (back of the head) due to these neural connections and the anatomical position of the sphenoid sinus relative to the occipital area. Incorrect Responses: (B) Vertex – This refers to the top of the head. While pain in the vertex can occur in various headache disorders, it is not the classic referral pattern for sphenoid sinusitis, making it less likely as the primary complaint. (C) Frontal – Frontal pain is more commonly associated with inflammation of the frontal sinuses rather than the sphenoid sinus. Since the frontal sinuses are located above the eyes, pain here typically presents in the forehead, not in the occipital region. (D) Temporal region – Temporal pain refers to the sides of the head and is not typically the area where sphenoid sinusitis pain is referred. This region may be involved in other headache syndromes, but it is not the hallmark of sphenoid sinusitis.

questions.text: 24 years old ramesh presents with pain over the bridge of the nose. It was aggravated by movements of eyeballs.Examination revealed oedema of both eyelids and swelling of the middle turbinate. Involvement of which of the following para-nasal sinus is suspected.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ethmoid Sinus is the most likely sinus involved. The ethmoid sinuses are located between the eyes and adjacent to the nasal bridge. Inflammation in these sinuses can cause pain over the bridge of the nose, which is often aggravated by eye movements due to their proximity to the orbital structures. Additionally, swelling of the middle turbinate is a common finding in ethmoid sinusitis since the ethmoid sinuses drain into the middle meatus. Incorrect Responses: (A) Maxillary Sinus – This sinus is located in the cheek area, and its involvement typically presents with pain in the upper cheeks or teeth rather than over the nasal bridge. It does not usually cause swelling of the middle turbinate or periorbital edema. (C) Frontal Sinus – Involvement of the frontal sinus generally causes pain in the forehead region, not over the bridge of the nose. It is less likely to affect the middle turbinate, which is more closely associated with the ethmoid sinuses. (D) Sphenoid Sinus – Sphenoid sinusitis typically presents with deep, vague pain that may be referred to the occipital or vertex regions. It does not characteristically cause pain over the nasal bridge or swelling of the middle turbinate.position.

questions.text: Pain in vertex is seen in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sphenoid sinusitis is most commonly associated with vertex pain. The sphenoid sinus is situated deep within the skull, and its inflammation often results in a diffuse, deep-seated headache that is frequently referred to the vertex (top of the head). This pattern of pain referral is due to the sinus’s proximity to central neural structures and its unique innervation, making vertex pain a characteristic feature of sphenoid sinusitis. Incorrect Responses: (A) Ethmoid sinusitis – This typically presents with pain localized to the nasal bridge and periorbital area, not at the vertex. Inflammation of the ethmoid sinuses usually causes pain between or behind the eyes and along the nose rather than the top of the head. (C) Frontal sinusitis – Involvement of the frontal sinuses generally results in pain concentrated in the forehead region. The pain in frontal sinusitis is usually felt above the eyes or in the central forehead, not at the vertex. (D) Maxillary sinusitis – This condition usually manifests as pain in the cheek area, upper teeth, or the side of the face. It is not typically associated with vertex pain since the maxillary sinuses are located in the cheek region rather than near the vertex.

questions.text: Incidence of mucocele is lowest in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sphenoid sinus – Mucocele formation in the sphenoid sinus is rare compared to the other paranasal sinuses. The sphenoid sinus, located deep in the skull with a relatively wide drainage pathway, is less prone to the blockage that leads to mucocele formation. As a result, among the sinuses, the sphenoid has the lowest incidence of mucocele. Incorrect Responses: (A) Frontal sinus – Frontal sinus mucoceles are the most common type because the frontal sinus has a narrow ostium which predisposes it to obstruction and subsequent mucocele formation. (C) Maxillary sinus – Although less common than frontal mucoceles, mucoceles of the maxillary sinus occur more frequently than those of the sphenoid sinus due to different drainage dynamics and anatomical factors. (D) Ethmoid sinus – The ethmoid sinuses, with their complex anatomy and numerous small air cells, are more likely to develop mucoceles than the sphenoid sinus, making their incidence higher than that of the sphenoid sinus.

questions.text: Most severe complication of maxillary sinus lavage and insufflation-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Air embolism is the most severe complication of maxillary sinus lavage and insufflation. During the procedure, pressurized air is introduced into the maxillary sinus to help clear debris and enhance drainage. If the air is inadvertently forced into a vascular channel or if there is a breach in the mucosal barrier, it can enter the bloodstream, leading to an air embolism. This event can cause rapid cardiovascular collapse, neurological deficits, and potentially fatal outcomes, making it the most serious complication. Incorrect Responses: (A) Facial nerve injury – This is not typically associated with maxillary sinus lavage. The facial nerve is anatomically distant from the maxillary sinus and is not usually at risk during this procedure. (C) Epistaxis – While nosebleeds can occur during or after sinus procedures, they are usually mild and self-limiting. Epistaxis is a relatively common and less severe complication compared to an air embolism. (D) Coagulopathy – Coagulopathy, a disorder of blood clotting, is not a direct consequence of maxillary sinus lavage and insufflation. It is not considered a procedural complication in this context.

questions.text: A 45 year old lady presented with complaints of nasal congestion , stuffiness ,discharge and anosmia . CT scan of paranasal sinus was done as shown below what is the diagnosis :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Allergic Fungal Sinusitis is the diagnosis. This condition is the most common type of fungal sinusitis, typically seen in patients presenting with nasal congestion, stuffiness, discharge, and anosmia. It results from type I and III hypersensitivity reactions to fungal antigens, most commonly Aspergillus fumigatus. On CT scans, allergic fungal sinusitis is characterized by heterogeneous opacification of the sinuses due to the presence of allergic mucin mixed with fungal debris and nasal polyps. The management involves functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) combined with corticosteroids, while antifungals are reserved for invasive fungal sinusitis rather than the allergic type. Incorrect Responses: (A) Ethmoidal Polyp – This option is less likely because ethmoidal polyps typically present as homogeneously opacified soft tissue masses on CT scans and are usually associated with chronic rhinosinusitis rather than the heterogeneous appearance seen in allergic fungal sinusitis. (B) Antrochonal Polyp – An antrochoanal polyp is usually a unilateral, benign lesion arising from the maxillary sinus and extending into the nasopharynx. Its imaging features and clinical presentation differ from the bilateral, heterogeneous opacification typical of allergic fungal sinusitis. (D) Nasoethmoidal Carcinoma – Carcinoma in the nasoethmoidal region would likely present with more aggressive features such as bone destruction and localized mass effect, rather than the characteristic allergic mucin and heterogeneous sinus opacification seen in allergic fungal sinusitis.
